title-group.article-title: Expression Profile of Extracellular Matrix and Adhesion Molecules in the Development of Endometriosis in a Mouse Model

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pathology, Tochigi Institute of Clinical Pathology, Tochigi, Japan
2Department of Hygienic Chemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Tokyo University of Science, Noda, Chiba, Japan
3The Center for Environmental Health Science for the Next Generation, Research Institute for Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Science, Noda, Chiba, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Masakazu Umezawa, The Center for Environmental Health Science for the Next Generation, Research Institute for Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Science, 2641 Yamazaki, Noda, Chiba 278-8510, Japan Email: masa-ume@rs.noda.tus.ac.jp

abstract.p: Ectopic endometrial tissue induces various reactions in surrounding tissues, such as the surface of the ovary and peritoneal cavity, leading to endometriosis. The aim of this study is to investigate the expression profile of extracellular matrix (ECM) and adhesion molecules in the early steps of development of experimental mouse endometriosis, specifically in peritoneum adjacent to endometrium transplants attached via autotransplantation. The endometriosis model was induced by autotransplantation of endometrium to peritoneal tissue. Peritoneal tissues adjacent to the transplant were obtained at 1, 4, and 7 days posttransplantation. The results showed that messenger RNA expression levels of most of the integrins, collagens, and other ECM reached a peak at 7 days posttransplantation. Uniquely, Lamc2 was significantly increased to its maximum level within 24 hours posttransplantation and may be strongly associated with initiation of the development of endometriosis. These data will be helpful in further investigations of the treatment of endometriosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The endometrium transferred to the peritoneal cavity causes immunoinflammatory reactions in surrounding tissues, such as the surface of the ovary, peritoneal cavity, and rectovaginal septum, leading to development of endometriosis. This disorder is defined by the presence of tissue implants resembling endometrial glands at ectopic sites outside the uterus. It affects about 10% of women of reproductive age and causes pelvic pain and infertility. 1 However, details of the pathogenesis of this condition are still unclear and effective treatments that conserve fertility and prevent recurrence have not yet been established. To overcome such limitations, it is necessary that the mechanism of endometriosis development be revealed.

To investigate the pathogenic factors of endometriosis, rodent models with autotransplantation of endometrium have previously been developed. 2
–5 In the disease models, observations consistent with human endometriosis such as infiltration of mast cells and granulocytes have been found in the peritoneal side of the stromal tissue rather than in the transplant. 2,6,7 The autotransplantation model of endometriosis has also been used for studies of disease-related infertility 8 and epigenetic programming. 9 A recent study based on gene expression analysis showed that upregulation of genes associated with cell adhesion and the extracellular matrix (ECM) precedes formation of endometriotic lesions pathology and upregulation of expression of cytokines and chemokines during development of endometriosis in the mouse model. 7,10 Previous studies have found that eutopic and ectopic endometrial stromal cells from women with endometriosis exhibit an aberrant integrin profile compared with stromal cells derived from healthy controls. 11,12 Endometrial cell adhesion and proliferation in the pathogenesis of endometriosis is likely to be modulated by the interaction of integrin receptors with ECM components. However, detail of the expression profile of molecules associated with cell adhesion in the early steps of development of endometriosis is still unknown. It is important to reveal the expression pattern in the early steps of pathogenesis as this is when the response of the peritoneal tissues to the ectopic endometrium is initiated. The purpose of the present study is to investigate the expression profile of the ECM and adhesion molecules in the development of endometriosis in a mouse model.

sec.title: Animals and Treatments
sec.p: Twenty ICR mice were purchased from Japan SLC Inc (Shizuoka, Japan) and randomly divided into endometriosis group (n = 12) and sham-operated group (n = 8). They were housed in a controlled room with ad libitum access to chow and water. All animals were treated and handled in accordance with national guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals and with the approval of Tokyo University of Science’s Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee.

Endometriosis was induced in female mice at 8 weeks of age, when a 5 × 5 mm piece of uterine tissue was attached to each side of the peritoneum by surgical autotransplantation (n = 2 per mouse). Peritoneal tissues adjacent to the endometrial transplant were obtained as endometriotic lesions at 1 (n = 8 from 4 mice), 4 (n = 8 from 4 mice), and 7 (n = 8 from 4 mice) days posttransplantation. As a control (sham-operated group), a piece of abdominal white adipose tissue was autotransplanted to each side of the peritoneum (n = 2/mouse). Peritoneum adjacent to adipose transplant was obtained at 1 (n = 6 from 3 mice), 4 (n = 4 from 2 mice), and 7 (n = 6 from 3 mice) days posttransplantation. Peritoneum only (excluding the transplant) was provided into gene expression analysis.

sec.title: Histological Analysis
sec.p: Tissue samples for microscopic analysis were fixed in phosphate-buffered fixative (4% vol/vol [v/v] formaldehyde, 1% v/v glutaraldehyde). They were dehydrated in ethanol and embedded in paraffin. To confirm the peritoneal proliferative lesion, which is characterized by interstitial stromal hyperplasia with fibroblast infiltration, 2 sections (5 μm) were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and analyzed by light microscopy.

sec.title: Gene Expression Analysis by Quantitative Real-Time PCR
sec.p: Total RNA was extracted from the tissue samples, peritoneum only and the transplant (fat or uterine tissue) removed, and reverse-transcribed into complementary DNA (cDNA) as previously described. 3 Briefly, RNA was isolated with Isogen (Nippon Gene Co, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan) followed by treatment with DNase (Promega Co, Wisconsin), and was reverse-transcribed into cDNA using M-MLV reverse transcriptase (Invitrogen Co, California) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was performed using SYBR Green Real-time PCR Master Mix (Toyobo Co, Ltd, Osaka, Japan) with an Mx3000P Real-Time PCR System (Stratagene, La Jolla, California) and a PRISM 7700 Sequence Detection System (Perkin-Elmer Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Relative expression levels were calculated for each sample after normalization against the housekeeping gene, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. Primer sequences and Tm values of PCR reaction and the gene name descriptions are shown in Table 1. Statistical analysis was performed with Kruskal-Wallis test followed by Steel-Dwass test to compare the groups.

caption.p: Sequences and Tm Values of the Primers Probe Used in Real-Time PCRa

fn.p: a Gene Name: Itga1, integrin alpha 1; Itga2, integrin alpha 2; Itga3, integrin alpha 3; Itga4, integrin alpha 4; Itga5, integrin alpha 5; Itga6, integrin alpha 6; Itgav, integrin alpha V; Itgb1, integrin beta 1; Itgb3, integrin beta 3; Col1a1, collagen, type I, alpha 1; Col3a1, collagen, type III, alpha 1; Col8a1, collagen, type VIII, alpha 1; Col11a1, collagen, type XI, alpha 1; Fn1, fibronectin 1; Tnc, tenascin C; Vtn, vitronectin; Lamc1, laminin, gamma 1; Lamc2, laminin, gamma 2; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.

sec.title: Pathological Evaluation of the Mouse Endometriosis Model
sec.p: Transplants induced a model of endometriosis, with proliferation of peritoneal stromal cells at 4 and 7 days posttransplantation. The proliferative lesions in the peritoneal stroma adjacent to the autotransplanted endometrium reached the medial abdominal muscle at 4 and 7 days posttransplantation (Figure 1). This result is consistent with a previous report. 7 At 24 hours posttransplantation, stromal proliferative lesions were not observed. 7

caption.p: Histological features of the mouse endometriosis model at 4 and 7 days posttransplantation. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE)-stained images of peritoneal tissue adjacent to autologously transplanted white adipose tissue (A, 4 days; B, 7 days posttransplantation) or endometrium (C, 4 days; D, 7 days posttransplantation) are shown. Scale bar indicates 200 μm. Double-headed arrows indicate proliferative lesions of the endometriosis model. Abbreviations: AM, abdominal muscle; Int, internal; Med, medial; Ext, external.

sec.title: Expression of mRNA Encoding ECM in the Mouse Endometriosis Model
sec.p: The levels of messenger RNA (mRNA) expression encoding ECM were measured in this study. At 7 days posttransplantation, expression levels of Col3a1, Col8a1, Col11a1, Tnc, Vtn, Lamc1, and Lamc2 mRNAs were significantly increased in the mouse endometriosis model compared to the control tissues, comprising peritoneal tissues on which white adipose tissue had been transplanted autologously (Figure 2). Our unpublished data suggested that expression of mRNAs encoding ECM tended to be decreased at 14 days posttransplantation (but the data were difficult to be obtained because the endometrial transplant was degenerated at this time point) compared with day 7. Lamc2 expression was significantly and uniquely increased to its maximum level within 24 hours posttransplantation (Figure 2I). Col1a1 and Fn1 expression levels tended to be increased in the mouse endometriosis model compared with control, but the difference was not statistically significant because of a large variance of the expression levels in each tissue sample (Figure 2A and E). Vtn and Lamc1 expression levels were increased in the control tissues at 4 days posttransplantation, suggesting that expression levels of the mRNAs in the peritoneal tissues were increased independently of the attached transplant (Figure 2G and H).

caption.p: Expression pattern of messenger RNA (mRNA) encoding extracellular matrix in the mouse endometriosis model. Peritoneum only excluding the transplant (fat or uterine tissue) was provided into RNA isolation followed by gene expression analysis with quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Data are shown as means ± standard deviation (SD). Kruskal-Wallis test followed by Steel-Dwass test was conducted to determine significant differences in the mean level of gene expression between the groups. *P < .05 significantly different.

sec.title: Expression of mRNA Encoding Integrin Subunits in the Mouse Endometriosis Model
sec.p: In the present study, the levels of mRNA expression encoding integrin subunit proteins were also examined. At 7 days posttransplantation, expression levels of integrin α2, α3, α6, and β3 mRNAs were significantly increased in the mouse endometriosis model compared with the control tissues (Figure 3). An increase in expression of integrin α2 mRNA at 24 hours posttransplantation was statistically significant, and the expression level was very low compared to the lesions at 4 and 7 days posttransplantation (Figure 3B). Integrin α1, α4, α5, and αv expression tended to be increased in the mouse endometriosis model compared with control, but the difference was not statistically significant (Figure 3A, D, E, and G).

caption.p: Expression pattern of messenger RNA (mRNA) encoding integrin subunits in the mouse endometriosis model. Peritoneum only excluding the transplant (fat or uterine tissue) was provided into RNA isolation followed by gene expression analysis with quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Data are shown as means ± standard deviation (SD). Kruskal-Wallis test followed by Steel-Dwass test was conducted to determine significant differences in the mean level of gene expression between the groups. *P < .05 significantly different.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: At the present time, the etiology of endometriosis remains unclear. Sampson hypothesis, 13 which proposes the involvement of retrograde seeding of endometrial cells during menstruation, is widely accepted. However, the details of the pathogenesis are still unclear and therefore it is important to investigate what changes are induced in the surrounding tissues by ectopic endometrium. Previous studies have suggested that ectopic endometrium overexpresses matrix metalloproteinases. 4,14,15 Matrix metalloproteinases degrade basal lamina containing laminin, fibronectin, and collagen and support cell invasion, 16 –18 which can lead to the development of endometriosis. It has also been reported that immunoinflammatory reactions are induced in human endometriosis 6,19 and endometriosis models in animals. 2 –4,7 The homologous transplantation disease model used in the current study has the advantage of allowing investigations of immune responses induced by autotransplantation, which is close to the situation in human endometriosis. 3,10,20 Previously, we found an upregulation of genes associated with inflammation, such as Pycard in the peritoneal side of the lesion of the mouse endometriosis model after 96 hours of autotransplantation of endometrium and showed increased expression of genes associated with cell adhesion and ECM in the earlier stages of lesion development. 7 The expression level of genes associated with cell adhesion and ECM was independent of the estrous cycle. Cell–cell interaction and cell–matrix (ECM) interaction play important roles in survival and proliferation of endometrial cells in the peritoneal cavity. Klemmt et al12 showed that some specific ECM ligands for integrin, including fibronectin and collagen, promote adhesion and proliferative activity of endometrial cells in vitro. Association of ECM and integrins with the pathology of endometriosis has been well reported. 21,22 However, expression profile of these molecules in the early steps of the pathogenesis had been unknown.

The present study revealed the expression profiles of ECM and adhesion molecules during the development of endometriosis in a mouse model. The genes for analysis were reported to be associated with human endometriosis, 12 and therefore they may contribute to the pathogenesis of endometriosis. The genes encoding collagen which are typical as fibrillar and nonfibrillar molecules 23 were also selected for analysis. Expression levels of most of integrins, collagens, and other ECM mRNAs showed a peak at 7 days posttransplantation. Stromal proliferative lesions in the peritoneum adjacent to the autotransplanted endometrial tissue reached their maximum extent at 7 days posttransplantation and declined by day 14. The results of the ECM expression patterns were consistent with the peak of lesion formation in the peritoneum following autotransplantation of endometrium. 2,24 It should be noted that Lamc2 expression was significantly and uniquely increased to its maximum level within 24 hours posttransplantation. Laminins are the major noncollagenous constituent of basal lamina, one of the layers of the basement membrane, influencing cell differentiation, migration and adhesion, as well as phenotype and survival. 25 Laminins are heterotrimetric proteins that contain α-, β- and γ-chains, and reported to interact with α6β1 integrin in the development of endometriosis. 26 Lamc1 (laminin subunit γ-1) is a component of various types of laminin, whereas Lamc2 (the γ-2 chain) constitutes laminin-332, which is widely expressed in other epithelial tissues, together with laminin α3 and β3 chains. 27 Laminin-332 is reported to be associated with the migration of epithelial sheets in wound healing 28 and with the cell invasion process in cancer lesions. 29 Our data indicated that the molecule may also have an important role in the early steps of cell invasion in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. This hypothesis is supported by a previous report, showing the protein level of laminin was increased in human endometriosis. 30 The ECM interacts with integrin on cell surfaces and can modulate cell invasion, proliferation and differentiation. 31 It was also reported that increased expression of ECM may contribute to an immunotolerance to ectopic endometrium, 32 leading to the development of entometriosis. The present study also showed a peak in the expression levels of integrin α3, α4, α5, α6 and αv mRNAs at 4 days posttransplantation. However, expression levels of mRNAs encoding these molecules in the control tissues were relatively high at 4 days posttransplantation, suggesting that expression levels of the mRNAs in the peritoneal tissues were increased independently of the attached transplants. Integrin α2 and β3 may play more important role in pathogenesis. These data on the expression pattern of ECM and adhesion molecules should provide novel strategies for suppression of the development of endometriosis, such as the use of inhibitors of very late antigen (VLA)-4 (α4β1 integrin). 33 Both ECM and integrins may be upregulated by infiltration and proliferation of fibroblasts regulated by growth factors (transforming growth factor β34 and fibroblast growth factor35), or basal lamina disruption by matrix metalloproteinases in the lesion 4,16 –18 induced by ectopic endometrium. The autotransplantation model of endometriosis has previously revealed the effects of environmental factors on pathogenesis 24,36 and is expected to present a better understanding of the disorder. The disease model has revealed that some drugs inhibit the development of endometriotic lesions via different mechanisms. 14,37
–42 In these studies, Sugamata et al2,6 uniquely focused on the pathology in stromal tissues adjacent to endometrium transplant. The data presented in this work will assist further investigations of the pathogenesis and treatment of endometriosis in humans.

In conclusion, expression of collagen and noncollagenous ECM, as well as several variants of integrin, was increased in the early stage of development in an endometriosis model that was induced by autotransplantation of endometrium. It is of interest that upregulation of one of the major molecules associated with the ECM, Lamc2, precedes an increase in expression of mRNAs encoding other ECM molecules and formation of the pathology of the lesions. Further investigations focused upon the function of ECM and adhesion molecules may contribute toward clarifying the pathogenesis of endometriosis and create novel therapies for the incurable disease.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank Ms Rie Numazaki (Research Center for Health Science of Nanoparticle, Research Institute for Science and Technology, Tokyo University of Science) and Mr Hiroshi Hori (Department of Hygienic Chemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Tokyo University of Science) for technical assistance with the surgical procedure. The funder had no role in the study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
